        datagrid_widget = solara.get_widget(datagrid)

        def on_cell_change(_ignore=None, *args, **kwargs):

            df.value = datagrid_widget.data

        datagrid_widget.on_cell_change(on_cell_change)
        return lambda: datagrid_widget.on_cell_change(on_cell_change, remove=True)

    # wire up the events once
    solara.use_effect(connect_events, [])

A DataFrameHandler base class could define the core API (get_unique, get_value_counts, etc.) and any default logic reusable across types. Concrete classes (PandasHandler, VaexHandler) would inherit this and override only type-specific logic.

Some key benefits:

Remove duplication: Common logic lives in the base class. Concrete classes are lean.

Easily add new types: A new class (DaskHandler, XarrayHandler) inherits the interface. Cross filter automatically supports the new type, no changes needed.

Interoperability: Cross filter works with any class inheriting the interface. External libraries built on the interface also support multiple types.

Avoid if-else logic: The base class dispatches the correct concrete class. Each concrete class focuses on one type.

Confidence from testing: Test the base interface, know concrete classes will work. There is also a base test class using pytest fixtures that the others can modify as needed.

Edit: this would also provide type hinting and other IDE conveniences

def use_interval(f: Callable, interval: float = 10.0, enabled=True):
    """
    Call a function periodically.

    Parameters
    ----------
    f
        Function to call periodically.
    interval
        Interval in milliseconds.
    """

    def run():
        if enabled:
            time_start = time.time()
            next_tick = time_start + interval
            while True:
                # instead of sleeping for 1 second, we sleep until the next second
                # this takes into account overhead and makes the timer more accurate
                f()
                time.sleep(max(0, next_tick - time.time()))
                next_tick += interval

    return solara.use_thread(run, dependencies=[interval, enabled])
```
